thread.title: Kick-starting a career in economics

author: Helena Pozniak
title: Kick-starting a career in economics
text: For more career advice, visit The Axis » Try to define economics and you soon begin to understand the breadth of the subject – and the scores of job options it offers, from the lucrative and linked worlds of banking, consultancy and finance through to the public and voluntary sectors. The Dictionary of Economics defines it as “the study of the production, distribution and consumption of wealth in human society”. According to the Bristol-based Economics Network , it’s about choices and the impact of choice. It’s a very traditional degree that prepares people well. Economics will never shut doors Economics is a social science with a technical core. Students of the subject will first grasp the use of maths and statistics before moving on to psychology, anthropology, history, politics and more. Students go on to pursue a suitably varied range of careers. As economics graduates, actress Cate Blanchett, former England cricket captain Andrew Strauss and Arsenal’s Arsene Wenger would all be comfortable chatting about supply and demand, balance of payments or income distribution. “It’s a very traditional degree that prepares people well. Economics will never shut doors,” says Gillian Murchie, careers consultant within the social sciences faculty at the University of Nottingham . Economics is associated with wealth and how it is created and lost, and graduates of the subject tend to do very well. Combination courses are popular, but employers also value a pure degree The latest figures from the Higher Education Statistics Agency show that economics graduates are among the top graduate earners, with a median salary of £24,000 - behind only doctors, dentists, vets and engineers. At Nottingham, 85.3 per cent of economics graduates found graduate-level jobs six months after graduation; slightly higher than the 81.2 per cent national average. Combination courses, such as economics with languages, econometrics or international politics, are popular, but employers also value a pure degree. Some courses focus on behavioural economics, which might lead to work within digital marketing As well as acquiring the more generic graduate skills, economists are comfortable analysing a wide variety of data, abstracting and simplifying a problem, understanding economic theory and modelling approaches, knowing how to apply economic reasoning to policy data – and other specialist skills prized by commerce and policy makers. “It really does keep choices very open,” says Murchie. “Some courses focus on behavioural economics, for instance, which might lead to work within digital marketing or brand management.” The roles listed below are just a small sample of potential careers, and the universities mentioned are just a few of the many that offer economics and associated degrees. Courses vary between universities, so it pays to delve into how and what you will be taught, and by whom. Investment analyst Pick this if you are analytical, numerate and competitive, and can summarise and communicate. The job: Researching investment opportunities and advising fund managers to help them make investment portfolio decisions. Providing insight on economic trends, interpreting financial information from different sources and understanding wider business and political contexts. Employers: investment management companies, stockbrokers and investment banks The universities: London School of Economics, Oxford, Durham, Exeter Actuary Pick this if you are numerate, can communicate to clients and apply mathematical, statistical and economic knowledge to real situations. The job: Actuaries apply theories on finance and statistics to solve business problems. They usually look at managing risk – how likely is it that an event will happen and what are the associated costs? Actuaries give strategic and commercial advice; they need to translate complex information to assist clients. Employers: Most commonly pensions and insurance companies, with opportunities to branch into emerging fields such as investment, healthcare and banking. The universities: University of East Anglia, Nottingham Trent, Portsmouth, Leeds – plus professional training Civil servant Pick this if you like getting to the root of problems, you are interested in influencing public policies and you can grapple with and communicate complex arguments. The job: The Government Economics Service is the largest employer of economists; currently it has around 1,400 of them on its books. Roles range from public health, criminal justice or labour market trends – joining as a fast-stream economist could enable you to have real impact. Employers: The Government Economics Service (incorporating roles in 30 departments) Universities: Warwick, Bath, Edinburgh, Leeds Market researcher Pick this if you enjoy statistics, behavioural economics and innovation. The job: Examining what consumers need, or how to reach new groups. Managing qualitative and quantitative research – from field surveys or focus groups to using statistical software to understand information, and identifying patterns and solutions. Employers: Larger companies or marketing agencies Universities: Brighton, Plymouth, Reading, Worcester As long as events such as the eurozone crisis, mass migration or the impact of new technologies dominate the headlines, economists will be in demand, says Professor Rebecca Taylor, dean of the Open University. “Any economist will have a valuable, considered view on these issues, as well as the ability to propose a way forward to help deal with these challenges. I hope that scale of opportunity will encourage many people to consider an economics degree.” • Find more tips for studying, working and gap years on The Axis
